Award.AwardTitle: AF: Medium: Collaborative Research: Multi-dimensional Scheduling and Resource Allocation in Data Centers

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Data centers and cluster computing platforms have become the dominant computational paradigms of the past decade, becoming the de facto method of executing Big Data workloads. Typically, the entire cluster is treated as a set of resources shared by multiple clients who submit jobs requiring different types of resources. To add to this heterogeneity (or dimensionality) in resource requirements, machines in a cluster can be heterogeneous in terms of resources they provide. In such settings, resources need to be allocated and priced appropriately so as to balance performance with demand.

In this project, the PIs seek to study job scheduling in data centers to optimize temporal Quality of Service metrics such as response time along with fairness, when jobs can have resource requirements that are multi-dimensional. The main question studied can be phrased as: How does the temporal nature of job scheduling interplay with the dimensionality of resource requirements, and how do these two in turn interact with the classical economic desiderata of incentives and fairness?

This project is differentiated from previous work in aiming to develop appropriate models and algorithms through the lens of theoretical computer science, particularly by a fusion of the disparate fields of approximation and online algorithms, algorithmic game theory, and stochastic optimization. The resulting insights will be used to also develop new techniques to address classical scheduling and game theoretic problems that have defied successful solutions. The project is interdisciplinary, and the theoretical models and techniques developed will be motivated by the application domain of new hardware architectures stemming from emerging technologies, and the heterogeneity arising from provisioning them within a data center. Further, empirical validations will be performed, both via simulation on traces from data center executions, as well as deployment and experiments on clusters. This will ultimately influence the design and deployment of internet systems that use and generate massive data.

The interdisciplinary nature of the project points to not only the need for training a pipeline of students from high school students to graduates and imparting to them the power of algorithmic thinking and its broader relevance, but also the necessity for bringing scientists, mathematicians, and system builders to the same platform for active exchange of ideas. Towards this end, the PIs seek to equip the next generation of students, including women and minorities, with the relevant algorithmic skills by an education plan that includes effective teaching and mentorship, as well as to broadly disseminate the proposed work by organizing workshops and by writing books and surveys.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Modern data centers consist of various types of resources, such as CPU, memory, and disks; these resources are shared amongst tasks submitted by clients. Furthermore, servers may provide different amounts of resources, thereby adding more dimensionality to the setting. Motivated by such applications, fair allocation has recently received much attention. The overarching goal of this project was to develop scheduling algorithms for data centers to optimize various quality-of-service metrics, such as average response time, while achieving fairness when jobs have multi-dimensional resource requirements. This was a critical research goal to sustain the advances of cluster computing technologies, which had been a powerhouse of economic and technological activity.


The key outcomes of the project are outlined as follows:


The project showed that the fair allocation called proportional fairness can be used by an online scheduling algorithm to minimize overall job latency, such as average completion time or waiting time of all jobs. This result was surprising because the two goals of guaranteeing fairness and minimizing overall job latency looked contradictory. Rather, our result demonstrated that the right notion of fairness was key to minimizing job latency when jobs have multi-dimensional resource requirements.


The project continued to extend the results to the more realistic setting where heterogeneous resources are grouped into clusters and data migration across clusters should be minimized. One striking aspect of the developed algorithms was that the key algorithmic procedure was inspired by game theoretical ideas, which demonstrated how game theoretical ideas could help develop scheduling algorithms minimizing temporal quality-of-services. 


The project also explored online load balancing, where jobs should be assigned to machines (or clusters). The goal is to optimize objectives defined by aggregating the load of the machines, thereby focusing on how loads are equally distributed across machines. The project yielded almost optimal online algorithms for various objectives and machines of varying degrees of heterogeneity. Our work offers an almost complete picture of positive results along with impossibility results for multidimensional online load balancing.


Finally, the project studied fundamental offline scheduling problems that are related. To name a few, the project gave almost optimal scheduling algorithms when preempting the jobs being executed was not allowed and showed how to better schedule fully heterogeneous machines to minimize the total weighted completion time of all jobs. More importantly, the works developed new algorithmic ideas that could be used in other applications.
